Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a new message from leadership: “Can you confirm the details for the external partner by noon?” I glanced at the clock—11:15. As a colleague, I knew the team counted on me to be responsive, to keep things moving. I started drafting my reply, but then an email popped up from an internal assistant. She wanted access to the client files I was working on, saying it would save her time if she could just look through them herself.

As a lawyer, I felt the weight of my responsibility. Client confidentiality wasn’t just a rule—it was a promise. I couldn’t just hand over sensitive documents, even to someone on our team, without proper clearance. But as a colleague, I didn’t want to seem unhelpful or slow things down. My inbox pinged again—leadership was following up. I stared at the screen, feeling the pressure build, torn between the need to be a supportive teammate and my duty to uphold the ethical standards of my profession.
